Award.AwardTitle: Research in High Energy Physics on the CMS Experiment
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all of the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model to date was recently confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the CERN laboratory near Geneva Switzerland. However, the Standard Model as it currently exists leaves open many questions about the universe, including such fundamental questions as to why the mass of the Higgs boson has the value it has. To answer these questions it is necessary to go beyond the present picture of the Universe described by the Standard Model to the next phase of development, Beyond the Standard Model (BSM). Investigations in BSM physics probe such questions as why matter dominates over anti-matter in the Universe, the values of the masses of the fundamental constituents of matter, the quarks and the leptons, the size of the mixings among the quarks, and separately among the leptons, and the properties of dark matter. The LHC is currently one of the foremost facilities for answering Beyond the Standard Model questions and studying the properties of the Higgs boson, and the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) detector at the LHC has as one of its primary functions to discover new physics beyond the Standard Model. The work proposed here will contribute to the upgrade necessary to handle the higher energy of the newly-restarted LHC and to analyze data from the CMS experiment to look for BSM physics through the search for two candidate theoretical particles for BSM physics, a heavy charged Higgs boson and the so-called Wprime particle.

This award will fund two aspects of the CMS experiment: 1) further searches for BSM physics and 2) help build the CMS Phase I forward pixel detector upgrade, which will enhance the ability of CMS to discover BSM physics. The physics studies enabled by this award are the searches for Wprime and Heavy Charged Higgs, two candidate theoretical particles for BSM physics. The presence of a signal in any of these channels would have profound impact on our understanding of particle physics, while establishing its absence would provide important constraints on models of physics beyond the Standard Model. The CMS Forward pixel upgrade will allow the precise vertex location, needed for all physics studies, even in the harsh environment (very high luminosity) expected in near future LHC running. The CMS Forward Pixel Detector uses state-of-the art silicon technology for particle detection combined with equally sophisticated readout electronics. Innovative techniques of radiation hard technology and bump bonding have been used in the current detector to meet the real estate challenges in a high radiation environment. These techniques would greatly enhance the life span of detectors used in outer space research and improve bio-sensing miniature devices for medical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Purdue University Northwest (PNW) is a member of the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) since 2005 and the only institution in Northwest Indiana with a high energy physics program at the fore-front of high energy physics colliders. This grant from NSF has supported the PNW High Energy Physics group to contribute effectively to the various research activities on CMS committed in the proposal. 

PNW has contributed to the development of the CMS Forward Pixel Detector geometry, extensively participated in the construction of the CMS Phase-I Pixel Upgrade and, Forward pixel disks at Fermilab’s Silicon Detector (SiDet) Facility. This award facilitated us to utilize our experience and expertise in becoming valuable members to the upgrade of the pixel detector, in both Phase 1 and now Phase II. We led the Prompt monitoring and quality of the CMS Phase I Pixel Detector, with our postdoc Dr. Tongguang Cheng assuming the managerial position of CMS Level 3 Convener, serving as liaison between the Alignment, Calibration and Database (AlCaDB) and Trigger Study Group, followed by CMS Level 2 Convener position for the AlCaDB group. This effort eventually won him the CMS Achievement Award in Summer 2020.

Our group performed physics analyses on the data delivered by the proton-proton collisions at the LHC. Our contributions include, Search for Spin-2 resonance, Search for top anti-top resonances and Search for Leptophobic Z prime particle, Search for a Heavy Neutral Higgs boson, Search for a Heavy Neutral Higgs boson, and Search for Anomalous HVV Couplings. 

During the period of the grant, the group consisted of the PI, a newly hired tenure-track faculty in 2017 (Dr. James Dolen), postdoctoral research associates, and undergraduate students, all of whom participated in the activities mentioned above. 

This award also led a very successful education and outreach component, under the auspices of PNW QuarkNet center, conducting high school teachers and students’ workshops to train in the area of particle physics detection and analyze LHC collider data. Developing on the success of the high energy physics program, a general education science course of immense popularity is offered by the PI, namely, “The Origin of the Universe”.  The discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012 and the subsequent detailed studies of it have put Purdue Northwest on the global map of discoveries, thereby elevating the reputation of a regional University involved in high profile research. The PI has given numerous lectures with a wide spectrum of audience and won several awards and recognition for her direct impact in innovations and influence in Northwest Indiana. 

Dissemination of the research work by all the members of the group, including the undergraduate students, at conferences and meetings remained an integral part of this award. The PI remains committed to promoting education for women and minorities in particular, and is a common face at events in the region, with regular media coverage. The success and mentorship of our group’s activities resulted in Dr. Tongguang Cheng taking a faculty position as a tenure-track Assistant Prof. of Physics at Beihan University in Beijing, China, also a member on CMS.
